bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John M. Gibson, September 21, 1951

div1.p: Hench provides Gibson, who is publishing a biography of Sternberg, an overview of his Reed research. Hench offers his opinion of the relationship between Sternberg and Reed. Hench lists several important parts of the yellow fever story that remain in doubt and hopes that either he or Gibson might find the answers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John M. Gibson, September 21, 1951
div1.opener:
September 21, 1951
Mr. John M. Gibson
State Department of Health
Montgomery 4, Alabama
My dear Mr. Gibson:
div1.p:
I have your letter of September 10 and am interested to know that you are
publishing a book on the life of General Sternberg. You are of course familiar
with the one that was published by the American Medical Association and
written largely by his wife.

I have spent 12 or 13 years collecting data regarding the conquest of
yellow fever in preparation to writing a book on it. I have travelled to
many places around the country unearthing data in attics, in collars,
visited Cuba several times, spent weeks in Washington hunting through
various records, etc., and hope in time to write a comprehensive book
on the subject. I am of course anxious to use the Reed-Sternberg
material for my own book. Much of it has never been published before.
The most important part concerns certain very personal and private letters
written by Walter Reed to his wife with confidential comments about
Sternberg's attitude toward the mosquito theory before and after Reed and
his colleagues proved the validity of Finlay's theory. Naturally I should
like to reserve these letters for my own book but if I can be helpful in
other ways, I should be glad to serve you.

I think you probably already know that the protagonists of Reed are strongly
under the opinion that before the work of the Yellow Fever Commission,
Sternberg was not interested in Finlay's theory. Then when Reed and his col-
leagues proved the validity of the theory, Sternberg of course accepted the
proof and in a very natural way “got on the band wagon”, as it were, and most
properly took delight in the work of one of his subordinates which reflected
glory on the Medical Department of the Army, including the Surgeon General
who had of course written the order creating the Board. However some of the
Reed protagonists were of the opinion that Sternberg got on the band wagon
rather precipitously and with such enthusiasm as to detract from the work
of his subordinate. I am telling you in confidence that Reed seemed to have
shared this viewpoint and expressed what might be called mild annoyance to
at least two people - to his wife and to his very close friend Major (later
General) Kean. Among other data I have typed interviews with General Kean on
this point. However if Reed was annoyed he kept his feelings under control
and maintained a strictly correct attitude in public and in his private re-
lations with General Sternberg and other colleagues.

Mr. Gibson, there are two or three important parts to this story which I have
not yet found answers for which perhaps you have and if you have not, I am
glad to give you these suggestions because I think the answers to them would
strengthen either your book or mine.

list.item:
(1) Under what circumstances was the Yellow Fever Board formed? Whose
idea was it first? Was It Reed's idea or Sternberg's? Sternberg was of
course extremely interested in yellow fever. When the epidemic of the
spring of 1900 broke out in Cuba he was of course concerned. Reed had
already visited Cuba on two or three occasions in 1899, was very interested
in yellow fever, was doing research on it and the general impression is that
Reed probably made the suggestion to Sternberg; Sternberg thought it over and
finally agreed and created the Board but we need much more data on this point.
Can you tell me whether you have the dope on this? I shall not ask you for
it as that is of course your material to use but I am curious to know.

(2) Just what did General Sternberg have in mind when he wrote the order
creating the Board? You have of course read the order and know how vague
and general it is.

(3) Are there any confidential notes by Sternberg to supplement the official
order? Published records state that Sternberg talked the matter over with
Reed as undoubtedly he did and made suggestions or “gave orders” to Reed by
word of mouth. It is amazing how little is known about those discussions.

(4) Reed and Sternberg apparently kept in touch with each other up to a
point when Reed was in Cuba but the letters and telegrams between the two
that I have been able to unearth are extremely few in number.

div1.p:
I hope indeed that some of the questions I have raised can be answered by
the material which the Sternberg family has given to you. You will certainly
be doing medical history a service in clarifying the matter but it is only
fair to you to know what I discussed in the earlier paragraphs of this letter.
Naturally Mrs. Sternberg (Is she still living?) had every reason to give her
husband whatever credit was his due in regard to the conquest of yellow fever
but certain people have felt that her book was one-sided and my own opinion
is that the relative paucity of data which Mrs. Sternberg and her colleagues
were unable to unearth for her book would seem to indicate that the going
was not easy. Certainly the data in her book does not demonstrate much
initiative or primary leadership on the part of Sternberg in the matter of
Reed's pursuit of the Finlay theory. I am trying to be very objective about
all this and I am perfectly willing, anywhere along the line before my book
is published, to be influenced by written records and indeed the reason I
have not yet published my book is that I am not satisfied with several parts
of it as it now stands. I shall be interested to hear from you further.

I regret that I have not had the privilege of seeing your book on Gorgas.
This morning I found that it was not in the Mayo Clinic Library, a serious
omission indeed.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: I have written the above to you as a personal note and I would not wish
you to quote it or any part of it without letting me know. I don't want to be
involved prematurely in a controversy.
